title-group.article-title: Research on rotating speed of a squeeze-film driven rotor based on near-field acoustic driving

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control for Mechanical Structures and Precision Driving Laboratory, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China

author-notes.corresp: Bing Jia, State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control for Mechanical Structures and Precision Driving Laboratory, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing 210016, Jiangsu, People’s Republic of China Email: jiabing@nuaa.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This work deals with the dynamics of a levitated rotor, which is also rotated by a fluid squeeze film created by a vibrating cylinder type stator. The model, which describes the transient behavior of the rotation of a rotor, by means of the squeeze film generated by a traveling flexural wave of the stator surface, is presented. In such problems, the control equations of fluid in the squeeze film are firstly simplified on the basis of several reasonable assumptions. These equations, together with control equation of the rotor, are solved by using explicit finite difference methods. Then, the vibration mode of pressure at the stable time and the transient rotating speed of the rotor with time are evaluated. Finally, the rotating speeds, with different parameters of vibration of the stator, the squeeze film and inertial moment of the rotor, are compared in order to study how to effectively increase and control the rotating speed. This paper will provide the foundations to study the driving technology of squeeze film and will be helpful in the design and application of non-contact ultrasonic actuators.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the 1990s, Japanese researchers, with the purpose of decreasing or avoiding frictions and abrasions between the stator and the rotor of the traditional ultrasonic motor, began to discuss a new type of non-contact driving system. They considered that they would increase rotating speed and avoid abrasions if the rotor was separated from the stator. Therefore, a new type of actuator – a non-contact ultrasonic actuator – was put forward by Nakamura (1990), Hiros et al. (1993), Junhui (1995), Junhui et al. (1997), Yamazaki (1996) and Hashimoto (1998). The working principles of this kind of actuator should be that, with two driving signals with π/2 phase shift both in space and time exerted on PZT disks that are affixed on the stator, a squeeze film is created by a traveling flexural wave of the stator surface; then, the rotor can be rotated by pressure gradients and shear stresses in the squeeze film.

Various kinds of non-contact ultrasonic actuators have been presented and the maximum rotating speed of most of these actuators is not more than 5000 rpm. In 2005, Ji and Chunsheng (2005) produced a prototype of disc-type non-contact ultrasonic motor and the rotating speed reached 6000 rpm. Unfortunately, in their work, a structural or a numerical model to describe the physical mechanism of the system was not provided. In 2003, Adi and Izhak produced numerical analysis to solve the non-contacting lateral transportation using gas squeeze film generated by a flexural traveling wave. Unfortunately, They did not adequately present the transient properties of the levitated object with parameters of actuator sizes and fluid mediums. In addition, there is a disadvantage in the structure mode that the computational domain should change with time, which is not reflected in the process of numerical analysis. In short, the approach to the study on how to increase the rotating speed has not been discussed in depth by researchers before.

In the present work, the transient properties of the rotor will be revealed. The rotor is rotated by squeeze film which is generated by a traveling flexural wave of the stator surface. When the rotor rotates, it is deservedly considered that the computational domain (the clearance between the rotor and the stator) does not change with time. So, in this paper we can draw lessons from the methods, which are derived from Adi and Izhak (2003, 2006), to solve the rotating speed of the rotor. This work begins by presenting the structures of a coupled system and describing the governing equations of the system. Then, the numerical procedure using explicit finite difference methods is employed for solving the coupled equations. In the last section, we present a numerical parametric study on examining the effect of the rotating speed.

sec.title: 2. Governing equations
sec.p: According to Taylor Proudman’s theorem, when fluid rotates with a large speed, it is reasonably assumed that the speed is independent of the vertical axis. So the structure mode can be simplified into two-dimension situations. In other words, the analysis of the fluid mechanics in the squeeze film takes into account only the momentum in the circumferential dimension. Furthermore, we see that the radii of the rotor and stator ( Rr , Rs ) are much greater than the thickness of the squeeze film in order to generate pressure gradients and sufficient viscous forces. As a result, we may reasonably assume that the pressure gradient in the radial direction is zero. For the sake of the above assumptions, we can provide the analysis process as follows.

On the basis of compressible and isothermal fluid medium, the control equations in cylindrical coordinates can be introduced as (1)1Rr∂∂θ (ρh3∂pμ∂θ )=12∂∂t (ρh )+6ω∂∂θ (ρh )-α∂∂θ (ρ2h32μ ) where ρ, h, p, μ, t are density of fluid medium, thickness of squeeze film, pressure, dynamic viscosity, and time, respectively. ω and α are angular velocity and angular acceleration of rotor. ρ, h, p, ω, and α are time-varying variables. The thickness of squeeze film (h) can be written as (2)h=ɛ-asin (2πft-kRrθ ) in which a, f, k are vibration amplitude of the traveling flexural wave, driving frequency, and wave number, respectively. In addition, the rotor is controlled by the dynamics function as (3)Jα=∫0 2π∫0 HRr 2 (h2Rr∂p∂θ+μωRrh+αRrρh3 )dzdθ-MD with J and MD being the inertial moment of the rotor and the drag moment of inertia. When the rotor is driven, the drag moment of inertia (MD), acting on the undersurfaces of the rotor in case of laminar flow, is one of the most important properties of the driven rotor. The magnitude of the drag moment becomes bigger with the increase in rotor speed, and will affect the settling time of the rotor speed. According to the structure mode, MD can be introduced as (4)MD=1.32842πμρω32Rr 4

The integrals in equation (3), which consist of three terms, represent the shear stress’s contributions to the twisting moment. The first term is due to pressure gradients in the squeeze film and the second term depends on the relative velocity, namely, the angular velocity in this paper. Adi and Izhak (2003, 2006) explained that as the relative velocity increases, the second term increases until equilibrium with the first term is reached, at which time the third term vanishes. However, we draw a different conclusion, which will be discussed later on.
In addition, the suitable boundary conditions and initial conditions are p=p0,∂p∂θ=0 forz=0,z=Hp=p0,ω=0,α=0 fort=0 where p0 is the pressure in ambient temperature.
Equations (1), (3), boundary conditions, and initial conditions represent the coupled equations of the structure mode which can be solved numerically by finite difference methods.

sec.title: 3. Solving the couple equations numerically
sec.p:
We introduce the following dimensionless variables which are demoted by a tilde: θ¯=θ2π,z¯=zH,p¯=pp0,h¯=hɛ,p¯=ρρ0,t¯=2πft in which ρ0 is the density in ambient temperature. Using the above dimensionless parameters, the normalized coupled equations may be written as (5)∂∂θ¯ (p¯h¯3∂p¯∂θ¯ )=A1∂∂t¯ (p¯h¯ )+A2∂∂θ¯ (p¯h¯ )-A3∂∂θ¯ (p¯2h¯3 )
(6)h¯=1-aɛsin (t¯-2πkRrθ¯ )
(7)α=∫0 1∫0 1 (A4h¯∂p¯∂θ¯+A5ωh¯+A6αp¯h¯ )dz¯dθ¯-MDJ with the six parameters in the above equations being A1=96π3μfRr 2p0ɛ2,A2=12πμωRr 2p0ɛ2,A3=παρ0Rr 2p0A4=RrɛHp02J,A5=2πHμRr 3ɛJ,A6=2πHρ0ɛRr 33J
And the boundary conditions and initial conditions are p¯=1,∂p¯∂θ¯=0 forz¯=0,z¯=1p¯=1,ω=0,α=0 fort¯=0

The coupled system should be solved as follows: firstly, ω and α at the current time is obtained through solving equation (7); then the parameters A2 and A3 are determined and pressure p¯ at the next step time is obtained through solving equation (5), and at that time MD is obtained by equation (4). We mesh the cylindrical surface of the rotor on which the coupled system transfers the solution parameters. The solution parameters in the computation plane are stored in each meshing point. By using a finite-difference scheme in space, we obtain the discredited equations as (8)A1∂p¯∂t¯=-A1p¯i,jh¯i,j (∂h¯∂t¯ )i,j+p¯i,jh¯i,j 2 (∂2p¯∂θ¯2 )i,j +3p¯i,jh¯i,j (∂p¯∂θ¯ )i,j (∂h¯∂θ¯ )i,j-A2 (p¯i,jh¯i,j (∂h¯∂θ¯ )i,j+ (∂p¯∂θ¯ )i,j ) +A3 (2p¯i,jh¯i,j 2 (∂p¯∂θ¯ )i,j+3p¯i,j 2h¯i,j (∂h¯∂θ¯ )i,j )
(9)α=∑i,j (A4h¯i,j (∂p¯∂θ¯ )i,j+A5ω1h¯i,j )Δθ¯Δz¯-MDJ1-∑i,jA6P¯i,jh¯i,jΔθ¯Δz¯

In equations (8) and (9), the first order derivative of pressure is expressed by forward difference approximation and the second order derivative is expressed by central difference approximation. The spatial and time derivatives of the thickness of squeeze film are written as (10)∂h¯∂t¯=-aɛcos (t¯-2πkRrθ¯ )
(11)∂h¯∂θ¯=-2πkRraɛcos (t¯-2πkRrθ¯ )

Table 1 shows the related parameters in the numerical analysis. We firstly consider air as the fluid medium and divide the rotor height into 20 components and the circumference into 32 components. In the process of numerical analysis, we assume that the gas is isothermal according to whether the thickness of squeeze film is much smaller than the circumference of the rotor. As a matter of fact, the temperature in the squeeze film rises more or less when the stator is working. The energy consumption resulting from a rising temperature may be the main factor causing a decrease in rotating speed. In order to realize that the fluid is isothermal, we consciously set the height-radius ratio as correctly small. Table 1.
Related parameters in the numerical analysis
Grid interval Δz 0.05
Grid interval Δθ 0.03125
Air density (Kg/m3) 1.18
Air pressure (MPa) 1.01325
Air viscosity (Pa·s) 1.79 × 10−5
Rotor radius (m) 0.020
Rotor height (m) 0.005
Rotor density (Kg/m3) 2700
Clearance (m) 0.0002
Driving frequency (kHz) 20
Vibration amplitude (m) 1.0 × 10−6
Wave number 4

sec.title: 4. Results
sec.p: In the process of programming, we set the stability criterion that the rotating speed is stable if the error of the rotating speed between two time steps is within 10−20. In order to satisfy the Courant-Friedrichs-Lew (CFL) conditions, the time is discredited at a regular interval of Δt¯=2.0096×10-4.

When the rotating speed is stable, with time step number being about 3450, the pressure mode in the computation plane is shown in Figure 2(a). As can be seen, the pressure difference in the squeeze film would be less than the normal atmospheric pressure with three orders of magnitude. Figure 2(b) shows the rotating speed of rotor with time. From Figure 2(b), we can conclude that the rotor rotates slowly and the acceleration is very small at the beginning. With increasing time, the acceleration increases and the rotor rotates more and more quickly, and then stabilizes at a certain rotating speed. Figure 2.
The pressure mode at stable time and rotating speed of rotor with time: (a) Pressure mode when rotating speed is stable with time step being 3450; (b) Rotating speed of rotor with time.

As mentioned in Section 2, the rotation of the rotor is mainly affected by pressure gradients and viscous forces. We can also compare the influences of the two aspects upon the rotating speed. According to the integrals in equation (3), we name the first term SUM1, and the second term SUM2. Figure 3 shows the values of SUM1 and SUM2 at each time step. As can be seen, at approximately the first 200 periods, the amplitude of SUM1 is larger than that of SUM2. Thus, at this stage, the pressure gradients play a major role in rotating speed. We can also see that the rotor does not rotate if there are no pressure gradients in the squeeze film. But after this stage, the second term plays an increasingly important part in rotating speed. With increasing rotating speed, the second term increases synchronously. When the rotor is stable the amplitude of SUM2 is more than that of SUM1 with five orders of magnitude. Therefore, we can draw the conclusion that the pressure gradients and viscous forces are vitally important in different time stages, and the viscous forces increase until the equilibrium with the drag moment of inertia is reached. Figure 3.
Influences of the two aspects upon the rotating speed.

The key factors affecting the rotation of the rotor include input power and loads. According to a certain driving frequency and medium in the squeeze film, the vibration amplitude of the stator depends on the input power. As an actuator, in addition to the drag moment of inertia (MD), the loads are also reflected in the size and density of the stator, and the opposing forces resulting from the squeeze film. Therefore, we will in turn discuss the influences on rotation of the rotor exerted by vibration of the stator, the squeeze film, and the inertial moment of the rotor, respectively.

sec.title: 4.1. Vibration of stator
sec.p:
The parameters of the stator impacting on the rotating speed of the rotor mainly include vibration amplitude, wave number, and driving frequency. Figure 4 shows the rotating speeds with different vibration amplitudes of the stator surface (0.8 um, 0.9 um, 1.0 um 1.1 um, 1.2 um). As can be seen, the rotating speed increases with increasing vibration amplitude. We may increase the vibration amplitude to improve the rotating speed of the rotor. For a given cylinder stator, the natural frequency increases with increasing wave number. Thus, we should comprehensively consider both parameters in the vibration of the stator. Considering a cylinder aluminum stator that drives the rotor with sizes in Table 1, with an inner diameter of 0.0404 m and an external diameter of 0.0464 m, we calculate that the natural frequencies with wave numbers of 5, 6, and 7 are 34.602 kHz, 49.987 kHz, and 67.661 kHz, respectively. Figure 5 shows the rotating speeds, according to different wave numbers, with the same vibration amplitude of stator surface when the thickness of the squeeze film is 180 um. As can be seen, in spite of different wave numbers and frequencies, the rotating speeds become stable at approximately the same time and with the same value. That is, compared with the vibration amplitude of the stator, the wave number and the corresponding driving frequency have less influence on the rotation of rotor. Figure 4.
Rotating speed of rotor with different vibration amplitude of stator.
Figure 5.
The rotating speeds with different wave numbers and frequencies and with the same vibration amplitude of stator surface.

sec.title: 4.2. Squeeze film
sec.p:
The thickness of the squeeze film and types of mediums can also have a strong influence on the rotation of the rotor. Figure 6 shows the rotating speeds with different thicknesses (180 um, 160 um, 140 um, 120 um) of squeeze film with the wave number of 4 and vibration amplitude of stator surface of 1 um. We reveal that, with the decreasing thickness of the squeeze film, the response time (from start-up to stability) decreases and the rotating speed increases more notably than that with increasing vibration amplitude of the stator shown in Figure 4. Other than gas, we could select some other fluid mediums, such as water, kerosene, alcohol, etc, as lubricants in the squeeze film. The densities of water, kerosene and alcohol are 998 kg/m3, 814 kg/m3, and 789 kg/m3, respectively. In addition, the viscosities of these lubricants are considered as 1.01 × 10−3 Pa·s, 1.90 × 10−3 Pa·s, and 1.19 × 10−3 Pa·s. For comparing convectively, it is assumed that we put larger input voltage, which is required to PZT electric actuators, to implement the same amplitude of these mediums with larger viscosity compared with air. Figure 7 shows the rotating speeds of water, kerosene, and alcohol, respectively, with the same vibration amplitude of stator surface and wave number. We can reveal that the rotating speed with the three mediums becomes small compared with air. The reason is that, despite the increasing shear forces, the drag moment of inertia (MD) increases exponentially by larger viscosity and density according to equation (4). Figure 6.
Rotating speeds with different thicknesses of squeeze film with the wave number being 4 and vibration amplitude of stator surface 1 µm.
Figure 7.
The rotating speeds for water, kerosene, and alcohol with the same vibration amplitude of stator surface and wave number.

Remarkably, when the medium is incompressible, the cavitations may occur. With the stator working, for positive squeeze there is no particular upper limit to the pressure generated, but for negative squeeze, cavitations may occur in the squeeze film when the pressure becomes lower than vaporizing pressure, and the pressure will not fall any further. We consider that when the temperature is 20℃, the vaporizing pressure of water, kerosene and alcohol are 2340 Pa, 3200 Pa, and 5900 Pa, respectively. When the medium is incompressible, the density will be considered as constant. So, equation (1) changes by extracting density (ρ), and dimensionless variable p¯ will not be equal to ρ/ρ0. In the calculation procedure of negative pressure, we see that when the pressure on the nodal points is smaller than the vaporizing pressure, the amplitude will be constant.

sec.title: 4.3. Inertial moment of rotor
sec.p:
The rotor also has an influence on the rotation properties by means of its own inertial moment. As we know, for a given radius-height ratio of the rotor, the inertial moment of the rotor is mainly determined by the density of the rotor. Figure 8 shows rotating speeds with three different densities of the rotor and with the same vibration amplitude of the stator surface. We suppose that the densities of aluminum, copper, and steel are 2700 kg/m3, 8800 kg/m3, and 7860 kg/m3, respectively. As can be seen in Figure 8, the rotating speed at a stable time remains approximately constant but the response time increases with the increase of density. Figure 8.
Rotating speeds with three different densities of rotor and with the same vibration amplitude of stator surface.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: We have theoretically and numerically examined transient responses of rotating speed of a cylinder rotor which is levitated by near-field acoustic levitation (NFAL) and driven by a squeeze film generated by the vibrating surface of a cylinder stator. After the simplification of control equations of the fluid medium, we used explicit finite difference methods to solve the dynamical behavior of the rotation of the rotor. In the process of analysis, the energy consumption resulting from a rising temperature was controlled by consciously setting the height-radius to be properly small.

By analyzing the pressure gradients and viscous forces, we made a conclusion that the pressure gradients and viscous forces are of vital importance on different time stages. We also in turn discussed the influences on rotation of the rotor exerted by vibration of the stator, squeeze film, and inertial moment of the rotor, respectively. The work in this paper will provide theoretical analysis methods by which we could increase the rotating speed and stabilities of the rotor of non-contact ultrasonic actuators.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Basic Research Program of China (973 Program) (2011CB707602), the China Natural Science Fund (grant number 11174149), and the funding of Jiangsu Innovation Program for Graduate Education (fund number CX10B_092Z).
